comments.commentBody: Obama could have done so much, but he did not. Of course conniving slogans manufactured by Axelrod, i.e. YES YOU CAN or was it YES WE CAN gave unimaginable hopes to different people at different levels. Obama went to Cairo, gave great speech, never followed up having raised unimaginable hopes there too. Through another lens, all this looks shady. And within a week of moving in the White House, his wife flies off, in OUR plane, to Paris to do, would you believe, shopping!! Why did she not do the same here in our USA, beats me. BTW, we elected him, and it is utterly preposterous to give her the title of First Lady! What exactly she did to earn this title, pray tell? Now both, Obama & his wife are totally focused on their legacy and the library, for which are we to pay or they? I have no idea. I am just asking!!

Mr Cohen,
When you write, "Americans are still hard-wired to American exceptionalism, the notion that America is not America if it gives up on spreading liberty." Here is another definition, from a dictionary :Exceptionalism is the perception that a country, society, institution, movement, or time period is "exceptional" (i.e., unusual or extraordinary) in some way and thus
does not need to conform to normal rules or general principles.

Lets look at the last line above: ...does not need to confirm to normal rules or general principles. It's this perception of "America's Exceptionalism" that I find to be the problem. Maybe Pres. Obama realizes that when the USA forays blindly into the much and mess of others, there's not really a heck of a lot that can be done other than spend trillions more while we grow only the Veterans Administration. Our Exceptionalism removed an anchor dictator in Iraq and created a sectarian war and gave Iraq to Iran. We flinched when Egypt democratically elected Morisi and stood by as General Sisi essentially replaced Mubarak. Obviously, a decision preferred by Israel and Liberty be damned.

Syria has basically been a mess since the end of WW1 when the Middle East was carved up by Sykes-Picot as the spoils of war to the French and British. I guess we could call that move the exceptional ego of the West.

I am no less horrified by the brutality on the innocent by Assad, Hezbollah, and Putin, but Obama's self questions are correct.
Obama asks, "Is it in USA's interest and is it winnable?" Cohen and other neocons would do well to answer those questions.
You have to be kidding.  Again no solutions.  Were we exceptional in Iraq and Vietnam. Mr. Cohen you need let go of all this nonsense.

I generally do not agree with Mr. Cohen, but his last two columns have been spot on. I am surprised, however, that he didn't bring up Obama's greatest "risk free" involvement where he failed to ask "what if" when he should have - Egypt and the overthrow of Mubarak. U.S. no-boots-on-the-ground pressure removed Mubarak in a matter of two weeks leading to chaos, battles on the streets of Cairo, persecution and murder of Copts, the one-time-only election of the Muslim Brotherhood and ultimately a military dictatorship not to mention alienating all of our long-term allies in the region. Why wasn't someone asking "what if" in the White House then?
Let us hope your hyperbolic analysys does not lead to a few survivors gathered around a camp fire a few years from today, muttering "I remember the run-up to WWIII."

Appeasement always loses.
We should intervene early.
Remember the run-up to WWII.
The U.S. military-industrial complex has spoken:  The U.S. will remain in Afghanistan.
By far the most successful manager of the US defence budget since WW2 was Eisenhower. He used the money to build national defence highways, now known as the interstates.

President Obama has many admirable qualities. He's tall, thin, attractive, has a good sense of humor, is a good speechifier, and has done an excellent job of providing for his family. I'd like to shoot baskets, eat Chinese and discuss women with him. But that is as far as it goes. He will leave office with the U.S. and Israel in peril in the Middle East and Russia on the ascendancy everywhere. At home -- for everyone with eyes in his head to see with -- his vaunted Obamacare program is already fraying badly around the edges, and he will bequeath us an economy
teetering on the edge of disaster. History's likely verdict:
a good man in a bad trade, a man disposed to blaming others for his difficulties, a man not given to having the buck stop on his doorstep.

Robert, do you remember the opening scene in Raiders of the Lost Ark? I HATE SNAKES! Just substitute METS for SNAKES. This series will either flush the pain of 1969 away or cause me to quit this Blog.  No Met will ever be my avatar.
Hank Hill and his Lady Bird won the Arlen Open.
Call me crazy, seems like a good subject for video.

Why exactly is it that the biggest hawks are always the ones who have no skin In the game and have never been in the arena? I was drafted in 1967 shortly after college graduation and ended up at the Pentagon where the last thing I did every day was to file a little piece of paper that detailed the name of a GI killed in Vietnam. I watched the Arlington National Cemetery grow down towards the Pentagon. We watched two draft dodgers start a phony war that cost trillions in dollars and uncountable human suffering with the results that the Middle East is in the midst of a religious war. So Mr Cohen please tell me exactly what military action you would take and will your children lead the charge to make America powerful again.

In a society where men are valued so much over women that 20 million girls are 'missing', it is hard for me to feel too deep about the 'plight' of men. As if it is easier for women to make it in the economic race! On the contrary; In China too, men still have the advantage in that respect.
Agreed 100%

It's perfectly proper to refer to the "acidification" of a solution, no matter how basic, when adding an acid to the mixture. The authors do not say the ocean is "acidic," which would be more to your point had they been loose with their terminology. They weren't. Ocean acidity is increasing even if not yet an acid solution per se, and the authors described it as such.
My contemporaries, now collecting SS, said the same thing.
Actually a democrat from NY already introduced a bill to use CPI-E because how it is calculated now is outdated and hurts our older population.

The Part B premiums discussed in this article are only part of the cost of Medicare.  You need to include Medigap  insurance which covers costs not covered by the government in Medicare Part B plus the cost of Medicare Part D for drugs.  My medical insurance bill for Medicare in 2016 will be $10,750 based on the info in this article and rates for Medigap and Part D.  Closer to what you are paying for 1 person?

Did you bother to read beyond the first paragraph? The OpEd cites the "West Coast shellfish industry" and "Alaska’s fisheries", which are not in the Atlantic.

And "the guys who have been measuring oceanic gases going back to George Washington's time" really do exist. The Times should provide footnotes with references, but in their absence, you can search for "ocean acidification geological record" at Google Scholar[1]. Here is a recent scientific paper on the subject:

The Geological Record of Ocean Acidification
Bärbel Hönisch et al
Science 2 March 2012
http://www.sciencemag.org/content/335/6072/1058.short

[1] https://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=ocean+acidification+geological+reco...

This OpEd would have been more informative if it had mentioned pH, but it is obviously addressed to general readers, who probably don't know what "pH" means. Anyway, a simple web search for "ocean acidification" found that "Since the beginning of the Industrial Revolution, the pH of surface ocean waters has fallen by 0.1 pH units."

What is Ocean Acidification?
http://www.pmel.noaa.gov/co2/story/What+is+Ocean+Acidification%3F

@lightscientist66: "One toxic algae has been known to affect people in boats, not even in contact with the water."

What is the name of this "toxic algae"?

Climate deniers will not admit that the oceans have absorbed 150 billion metric tons of carbon produced by man.  That would ruin their false argument that CO2 in the atmosphere hasn't increased that much in the past 15 years, as well as their carefully constructed falsehood that the average temperature in 1998 ( a strong La Nina year with spike in temperature) was no higher than 2012 ( a strong El Nino year with the lowest average temperature in decades).  Cruz loves to repeat that false comparison.

Mr. Gregory, you are correct in everything except the assertion that the original Americans lived lightly on the land.  There is overwhelming evidence that humans wiped out an immense fauna of large mammals when they arrived in North America perhaps 15,000 years ago, 34 genera of elephants, horses, camels, rhinos, giant ground sloths, bison, etc., and the great carnivores that preyed upon them.  Once humans left Africa, they eradicated large  wildlife wherever they arrived, slower in the case of Eurasia where we expanded in numbers slowly, very rapidly in North and South America, Australia and innumerable oceanic islands, where prey were naive to human hunting.   We are witness to the final stages of a long extinction that started when man became a capable hunter.  Romantic notions of hunter-gatherers as natural conservationists make a pretty story, but it is wholly untrue.

It is more than obvious that the political process will do almost nothing but pose and talk until the wolf is literally at the door relative to the environment. Private industry will not set aside a nickel of profit, individuals with the I've got mine mentality, the denialism/fatalism inherent in many religious sects and careerist politicians add up to inaction, disinformation and delay.

There is a way to live with the earth as a part of it, reliant on it, connected to it and respectful of it. We do not- as a species- live that way.

Our corporations and many individuals are treating the environment and the commons like a bankrupt business in liquidation. Factor in the tendency of capitalism to privatize the profit, but socialize (externalize or shift) the costs. We see this as industries see it cheaper to try lawsuits and buy politicians instead of cleaning up their factories, mines and business practices and conduct their businesses that way.

The first peoples of North America lived lightly on the land for countless generations and all we have as a result are potshards and petroglyphs, arrowheads and pueblos. In less than 600 years and in some places far less, we have polluted the land with radioactive wastes that will outlast humanity, toxics that have crept into the mother's milk of tribal peoples in the remotest corners of the earth and ravaged the richest bounty of nature like a drunkard in a liquor warehouse.

I would remind all: Nature Bats Last.

Nothing will be done until the pain caused by environmental degradation overcomes the profit motive.   I often think of the phrase that "a capitalist will sell his executioner the rope for their own hanging".  That rope already is around our necks.
